title: Primary Hyperparathyroidism with Nephrolithiasis
setup_script: A 55-year-old man presents with recurrent kidney stones and mild hypercalcemia. Serum calcium is 11.5 mg/dL (normal 8.5-10.5), PTH is elevated, and bone density T-score is -2.6. Neck ultrasound shows a 1.5 cm parathyroid adenoma behind the left inferior thyroid pole.

dynamic_flow.trigger: Review symptoms of primary hyperparathyroidism and indications for surgery, including stones, bone disease, and age <50.
Order 24-hour urinary calcium, vitamin D level, kidney imaging, and bone density to confirm criteria for surgery.
Explain guidelines recommending surgery for symptomatic and certain asymptomatic patients and obtain informed consent.
Discuss focused parathyroidectomy vs four-gland exploration; decide on minimally invasive approach with intraoperative PTH monitoring.
Plan preoperative localization studies (ultrasound, sestamibi scan) and discuss importance of rechecking vocal cord function pre-op.
Perform focused parathyroidectomy with intraoperative PTH drop >50% from baseline confirming excision.
Preserve remaining parathyroid glands and minimize manipulation to prevent hypocalcemia.
Postoperative management: monitor calcium and PTH levels; start calcium/vitamin D supplementation if needed.
Assess pathology to confirm adenoma and rule out carcinoma; document weight and morphology.
Monitor for hungry bone syndrome and symptoms of hypocalcemia; adjust supplements accordingly.
Arrange follow-up with endocrinology and nephrology for stone prevention and bone health.
Educate patient about hydration, dietary modifications, and need for periodic calcium and bone density tests.
